author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Majority of Supreme Court Appears Receptive to Biden Administration Limits on ‘Ghost Guns’
description: At issue was how the Biden administration had interpreted a federal statute to regulate kits that could be assembled into homemade guns, skirting background checks.
content: A majority of the Supreme Court appeared sympathetic on Tuesday to the Biden administration’s restrictions on kits to make homemade guns that skirted background checks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Troy Closson
title: School Absences Rise as Special Education Fails Students, Suit Says
description: A class-action lawsuit argues that the New York City school system falls short in helping students with emotional disabilities, leaving them to miss too many school days.
content: New York City “regularly fails” to provide special education services to students with disabilities, leading to chronic absences, according to a class-action lawsuit filed Tuesday by the Legal Aid Society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: As Hurricanes Strike, Insurance Costs Soar for Commercial Real Estate
description: Struggling landlords and developers are seeking leeway on coverage from their lenders — mostly in vain.
content: Postpandemic vacancies and surging debt payments have eaten away at commercial real estate for more than two years. Even as those threats start to fade, owners of strip malls, apartment buildings and office towers face a problem that could last much longer: soaring insurance costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Florida Rushes to Clear Helene Debris Before Milton Hits
description: Worried about flying wreckage, Governor Ron DeSantis said that the state was trying to clear as much debris from Hurricane Helene as possible before Hurricane Milton strikes.
content: Florida officials are scrambling to clear out the flattened trees, mangled appliances and waterlogged furniture left behind by Hurricane Helene to prevent the debris from becoming projectiles in Hurricane Milton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Top Musk Lieutenant Joins Trump Super PAC for Final Push
description: Steve Davis is often called upon by Mr. Musk to help in all-hands-on-deck situations, such as after Mr. Musk’s purchase of Twitter.
content: One of Elon Musk’s most trusted lieutenants has joined the crew of people working for his pro-Trump super PAC, the latest sign of how Mr. Musk is investing his personal brand, energy and network into the group in the final weeks of the presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Jenna Fischer, ‘The Office’ Star, Reveals Breast Cancer Diagnosis
description: “I am now cancer free,’’ the actress announced on Instagram, noting that she was diagnosed with Stage 1 cancer in December and that early detection had played a key role in her successful treatment.
content: Jenna Fischer, the actress best known for her role as Pam Beesly in the popular television series “The Office,” said on Tuesday that she was diagnosed with Stage 1 triple-positive breast cancer in December but that she was now cancer free after successful treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Pro-Palestinian ‘Uncommitted’ Group Comes Out Firmly Against Trump
description: The organization that emerged from protests against the Biden administration’s Middle East policies now says a second Trump term would be far worse.
content: Uncommitted, the national group of Arab Americans, Muslim Americans and Palestinian rights activists that emerged from primary-season voters protesting President Biden’s Middle East policy, took a big step Tuesday toward encouraging supporters to vote for Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Our Planet’s Twin Crises
description: In her last newsletter for the Times, a Climate Forward reporter reflects on the intertwined problems of climate change and biodiversity loss.
content: The world’s largest river, the Amazon, has fallen to its lowest level on record in the past few weeks, a development that has shocked experts around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Gazans Are Trapped in a Prison That Was Decades in the Making
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 8, 2024
content: “The world is not a kind and generous place.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Harris Spends an Hour in the Warm Embrace of Howard Stern
description: The shock jock has become a required stop for Democratic politicians.
content: Who says Kamala Harris’s unconventional media tour won’t reveal anything of note? On Tuesday, she did an hourlong sit-down with Howard Stern, the satellite radio host, and among the juicy bits we learned is that the V.P. isn’t a napper; that she digs Doritos and jigsaw puzzles; that her favorite F1 driver is Lewis Hamilton; that she went to see U2 at the Sphere; and that a rare area of musical agreement between her and Doug, her husband, is their love of Prince.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: How to Let People Down and Be OK With It
description: Setting boundaries often means disappointing others. We asked therapists for advice on how to do it — without feeling guilty.
content: In the last few years, several celebrities have captured the spotlight by stepping back to prioritize their mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: After Key Town Falls in Ukraine’s East, Russian Forces Push Into Another
description: Russian troops have now entered Toretsk, a strategic hilltop city, and are pressing with assaults elsewhere in the Donetsk region.
content: A week after Russia captured Vuhledar, a town that anchored Ukraine’s defenses in the country’s southeast, Moscow’s forces are continuing to advance in the area, pushing into or flanking several towns as they try to break through Ukrainian lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Morris
title: Shaker Cradles for Adults? They Rocked Frances McDormand’s Mind
description: A soulful exhibition curated by the actress and her friend Suzanne Bocanegra, an artist, explores caregiving and community.
content: On a Thursday afternoon in late summer Frances McDormand, the actor, and Suzanne Bocanegra, a conceptual artist, were testing out a Shaker cradle for adults. The exhibit of these little-known furniture items that they put together for the Shaker Museum’s pop-up gallery was days from opening in the Kinderhook Knitting Mill — a converted historic space in Columbia County, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: What Omarosa, John Kerry and Michael Cohen Have in Common
description: And why it matters in 2024.
content: Good evening! As former President Donald Trump threatens to prosecute his political rivals, my colleague Michael Schmidt, an investigative reporter, has an important look at how Trump deployed his power against his perceived enemies during his presidency. And we’re looking at the G.O.P.’s big bet on anti-trans ads. — Jess Bidgood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: A Florida Poll That Should Change the Way You Look at the Election
description: A big Trump lead in the state paradoxically adds to evidence of a smaller Electoral College edge for him. And a choice by pollsters may be causing them to miss state shifts.
content: We have three new New York Times/Siena College polls this morning. Only two look “normal.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 Takeaways From Harris’s Interview on ‘60 Minutes’
description: Pressed repeatedly, Kamala Harris stayed focused on the points she wanted to make. She also spoke about owning a Glock, and Tim Walz revealed she had told him to be a “little more careful” speaking.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris sat for an interview with “60 Minutes” that was broadcast on Monday night and, in a departure from some of her recent appearances on cable news and podcasts, she was repeatedly pressed on questions she did not initially answer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The $550 Million Question: How Does David Geffen Hall Sound?
description: The New York Philharmonic’s home underwent an extensive renovation that was finished two years ago. But that was only the beginning of the quest for the perfect sound.
content: When the New York Philharmonic English horn player and oboist Ryan Roberts performs at the renovated David Geffen Hall these days, he feels naked and exposed, as if he were appearing on a high-definition television screen.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Follow the latest updates on Hurricane Milton.

author: By Keith Bradsher, Chris Buckley and Meaghan Tobin
title: China’s Policy Reversal Sparks ‘Mind Boggling’ Stock Rally
description: The government has fired up investors by encouraging banks to lend more to buyers of stocks and real estate, but officials refrained on Tuesday from promising more stimulus.
content: Just a few weeks ago, many investors in China’s stock markets were ready to give up and eager to sell. Then late last month, traders rushed in to make bullish bets after the government’s leaders announced a series of steps to stimulate China’s faltering economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and JoAnna Daemmrich
title: Protest That the University of Maryland Sought to Prevent Goes On
description: The school, citing safety, had said no to an event planned on the anniversary of the Oct. 7 attack by a chapter of Students for Justice in Palestine, but a judge’s ruling last week allowed it to go ahead.
content: A pro-Palestinian student group gathered to mourn the lives lost in the war in Gaza on Monday, following a federal judge’s ruling last week against the University of Maryland’s plan to block it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: An Old Clash Heats Up Over Oppenheimer’s Red Ties
description: As a group of historians and a top biographer square off, proponents of a middle path see a tangled life in which the superstar of science was, and was not, a true Communist at the same time.
content: J. Robert Oppenheimer teemed with contradictions. He was shy and bold, naïve and brilliant, a loyal husband who cheated, a gentle man whose bomb could kill millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers: Trump Rallies Are Like an Escape Room
description: “Generally speaking, if you’re at an event and the host of that event keeps insisting no one is going to leave, it is time to start worrying,” Meyers said on Monday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wyatt Mason
title: Why France’s Most Controversial Novelist Is Also Its Most Celebrated
description: Reviled as much as he is lauded, Michel Houellebecq holds up a mirror to a world we would rather not see.
content: Michel Houellebecq — arguably the most important French writer of the past quarter-century — was perched on the seat of his chair like a bird. We were sitting in his dim Paris apartment in August, a spectacularly beautiful day visible through his curtained windows, to discuss his new novel, “Annihilation,” which appears this week and returns to the themes of male loneliness and civilizational decline that have made his reputation. During our time together, Houellebecq, who is 68, would slump deeper and deeper in his chair, to the point where it seemed he would need help rising, only to pop back up, with unexpected agility, to balance once again on the balls of his feet. I had been trying to ask him about his life, but he was deftly deflecting personal questions — he had been answering them for decades and seemed done with that dance — until I asked him to tell me a little bit about his early life as a reader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Warns Floridians to ‘Evacuate Now’ as He Postpones Foreign Trip Over Hurricane Milton
description: President Biden had been scheduled to leave for Germany and Angola on Thursday.
content: President Biden on Tuesday warned those in the path of Hurricane Milton to “evacuate now, now, now,” as he canceled a diplomatic trip abroad so he could oversee his administration’s response to the storm barreling toward Florida’s west coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Luis Tiant, Crowd-Pleasing Pitcher Who Baffled Hitters, Dies at 83
description: Cuban-born and charismatic, with a personal tale caught up in politics, he was a dominant hurler with a quirky windup who helped lead the Red Sox to a pennant in 1975.
content: Luis Tiant, a Cuban-born right-hander who was one of baseball’s most entertaining and charismatic pitchers, and whose personal story was among the game’s most poignant, died on Tuesday. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Our Book Is Here!
description: The cover star: Melissa Clark’s five-star skillet chicken with tomatoes, pancetta and mozzarella (a.k.a. pizza chicken).
content: Our cookbook has arrived! Today is the release of “Easy Weeknight Dinners: 100 Fast, Flavor-Packed Meals for Busy People Who Still Want Something Good to Eat,” inspired by this newsletter and all of you. I’m thrilled for you to see it. You can order your copy here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Death Row Inmate in Oklahoma Has an Unusual Ally: The State’s Attorney General
description: Both sides told the Supreme Court that long-suppressed evidence about the state’s star witness undermined the case against the inmate, Richard Glossip.
content: There is no dispute about this basic fact in the death penalty case the Supreme Court will hear on Wednesday: On a chilly morning in January 1997, in Room 102 of the Best Budget Motel in Oklahoma City, a handyman named Justin Sneed beat the motel’s owner to death with a baseball bat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Gee
title: Exposing the Violence of Empire in the Novels It Left Behind
description: For her new book, “Salvage,” the Trinidadian-born writer Dionne Brand rereads classic English novels, teasing out evidence of the ravages of colonialism.
content: Dionne Brand is a poet, novelist and essayist who was born in Trinidad and moved to Canada in 1970. She seeks, across all her work, to interrupt history. Or, as she puts it in her new book, “Salvage: Readings From the Wreck,” describing how the fiction writer John Keene blows “life into the collapsed world of coloniality,” she exposes histories that have not previously come to the surface, finding traces that were of little importance to the white writers of England’s colonial past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Reid J. Epstein
title: On ‘The View,’ Harris Hits at Trump’s ‘Callousness’ in His Storm Response
description: In a wide-ranging interview, the vice president also she could not think of a way she would act differently from President Biden, and laid out a plan to help Americans take care of aging loved ones.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, kicking off a daylong blitz of news media interviews, assailed former President Donald J. Trump for what she called his “callousness” in responding to the deadly storms that have ravaged southeastern states, and said she was still hoping to work with Gov. Ron DeSantis, Republican of Florida, as his state faces the latest monster hurricane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Cissy Houston Saw Music’s Peaks and Life’s Valleys
description: The singer, who died this week, was the mother of Whitney Houston and a contender for the greatest voice of the country, our critic says.
content: If you’re the sort of person who remains locked in a private, perpetual tug of war over whether the greatest singer this country’s ever known is Aretha Franklin or Whitney Houston, perhaps you’re also the sort of person who then spares a thought for Whitney’s mother, Cissy. Cissy Houston died at 91 on Monday, and she could sing, too. Let me try that again: Cissy Houston sang, first with the clarity of something just Windexed then, later, with a tone that acquired some protective, matured texture, some bark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Small Business Administration Will Soon Exhaust Disaster Loan Funds
description: The agency has less than $100 million for new loans, according to officials, while Hurricane Milton is headed toward Florida and after Hurricane Helene devastated much of the Southeast.
content: Small Business Administration officials warned on Tuesday that the agency would “very soon” exhaust its funding for new disaster loans for homeowners and businesses in the wake of Hurricane Helene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Toronto Woman Is Accused of Murdering 3 in Serial Killings
description: Victims who were found in a span of three days in Canada last week included two men whom the police said the suspect had attacked at random.
content: The first victim was a woman whose body was found with visible trauma in a home in Toronto last Tuesday. On Wednesday, the police found a second victim, a man, dying of unspecified injuries in a Niagara Falls park, about 80 miles away. On Thursday, a third victim, also a man, was fatally stabbed in a parking lot in Hamilton, a city some 45 miles from there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: Biden’s Moral Failure in Israel
description: The American president promised equality. He didn’t deliver.
content: Joe Biden’s presidency has a distinct origin story. As he tells it, he was done with politics, happily retired from public life. That changed after Donald Trump’s equivocal response to the 2017 white supremacist march in Charlottesville, Va. It was then that Mr. Biden realized that Mr. Trump and his allies threatened what he called the “soul of this nation”: its commitment to equality. So he re-entered the fray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Romney Won’t Endorse Harris, Saying He Wants to Keep His Voice in the Party
description: Senator Mitt Romney of Utah, the 2012 Republican nominee for president, says the party may need to be rebuilt.
content: Senator Mitt Romney, the retiring Republican from Utah and onetime standard-bearer of a party that has shifted under his feet, said Tuesday that he would not endorse Vice President Kamala Harris in the election because it might hamper a critical role he could play in helping to rebuild the G.O.P. down the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Vandals Deface Harvard Statue and U. of Michigan Leaders’ Homes
description: It was not clear who was responsible for the broken windows, fake blood and pro-Palestinian slogans.
content: A statue and an administration building at Harvard and the homes of two top administrators at the University of Michigan were vandalized, apparently by protesters sympathetic to the pro-Palestinian cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Mark Barrett
title: How Helene Has Upended North Carolina’s Election Plans
description: With 13 counties devastated by flooding, the state is trying to make sure that residents can still vote. Candidates have been forced to abandon door-knocking and phone banks.
content: For decades, the North Fork Voting House has served as the official polling place for nearly 600 residents in the small mountain community of Creston, N.C. The tiny cinder block building was recently updated with a freshly painted white door, handmade curtains for the voting booths and a new metal roof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: Qantas Apologizes for Showing R-Rated Film With Nudity to Entire Flight
description: The scenes played on every screen, according to comments from social media users. The airline has since said the movie “was clearly not suitable.”
content: Sit back, relax and enjoy the … nudity and sexting?

author: By Annemarie Conte
title: Protein, Pickles and Purists: There Are Many Ways to Drink Diet Coke
description: Opinions abound on how to customize the popular soda. Purists, meanwhile, will see you at McDonald’s.
content: The latest battle in the soda wars isn’t Coke versus Pepsi. It’s Diet Coke versus Diet Coke, and the fandom is bubbling over on social media.

author: By David L. Ulin
title: Reading With My Father
description: A conversation through books.
content: The last time I visited my parents, I borrowed a novel from the shelves in my old bedroom. Once, the books there belonged to me, but in the decades since I lived in this apartment, my father has commandeered the space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
title: For Many Israelis, Oct. 7 Never Ended
description: The Hamas-led attacks that day shattered Israelis’ faith in the state, and the year of war that followed has deepened society’s divisions. Yet many find hope in the people’s resilience.
content: Like other Israeli civilians, Geffen Yamin and Eyar Liv Halabi, project managers at Tel Aviv startups, rushed to fill gaps in the government’s initially paralyzed response when thousands of gunmen from Gaza poured over the border on Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Google Was Forced to Open Up
description: A federal judge ordered the tech giant to let rival app stores onto its Android smartphone platform, adding to its growing list of legal headaches .
content: Four years ago, Epic Games began efforts to disrupt the two major smartphone operating systems, Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android. While one of those fights largely sputtered, the other has yielded major results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
title: Brazil Unblocks X After Musk Backs Down
description: Brazil’s Supreme Court said Tuesday that Elon Musk’s social network could return in the country after a monthlong ban because the company had complied with the court’s orders.
content: Brazil lifted its ban on the social network X on Tuesday after its owner, Elon Musk, capitulated in his fight with the country’s Supreme Court, ending a five-week suspension of the platform across the nation of 200 million.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Russian Spies Seeking to ‘Generate Mayhem’ in Europe, MI5 Chief Says
description: The head of Britain’s domestic security service said Russia’s military intelligence service was pursuing “dangerous actions conducted with increasing recklessness.”
content: Russian intelligence agents are on a mission “to generate mayhem on British and European streets,” Britain’s spy chief said Tuesday in a wide-ranging speech that also warned of a rising threat from Iran and new efforts by the Islamic State to export terrorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney and Mira Rojanasakul
title: Record Hot Water Is Fueling Hurricane Milton
description: Milton grew into a Category 5 hurricane in less than a day as it crossed warm oceans across the Gulf of Mexico.
content: Hurricane Milton gained strength over the Gulf of Mexico extremely quickly on Monday, going from a tropical storm to a Category 5 hurricane in under a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘La Máquina’ Is a Starry Mexican Boxing Drama
description: The Spanish-language Hulu drama, starring Diego Luna and Gael García Bernal, skews more loopy and mysterious than gritty.
content: Diego Luna and Gael García Bernal star in the Mexican boxing drama “La Máquina” (in Spanish, with subtitles, on Hulu) as a promoter and his boxer bestie. Andy (Luna), who copes with stress by giving himself facial injections, has been friends with Esteban (García Bernal), the popular boxer known as La Máquina (Spanish for “the machine”), since they were kids. He tends to Esteban’s every need — including fixing a fight or two along the way, without Esteban’s knowledge.

title: TikTok Faces Barrage of Lawsuits Around Teens and Mental Health

content: Thirteen states and the District of Columbia sued TikTok on Tuesday, accusing the company of creating an intentionally addictive app that harmed children and teenagers while making false claims to the public about its commitment to safety.

content: Gazing up at the 60-foot wall in the central atrium of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Nigerian artist Otobong Nkanga felt both excited and terrified.

title: In Florida, Day Laborers Have Become the Backbone of Hurricane Cleanup
description: While they work, they face many risks, like wage theft or breathing in harmful dust and mold. Sleeping in a vehicle for weeks at a time is not uncommon, either.
content: William Lopez was still cleaning debris and covering the roofs of homes damaged by Hurricane Helene about 40 minutes north of Tampa this week when the warnings about Hurricane Milton started to become dire.

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Mass Evacuations Clog Highways in Florida Ahead of Milton
description: Officials said the evacuation was likely the biggest the state has seen since Hurricane Irma in 2017, and warned residents to leave early to avoid heavy traffic.
content: Residents along Florida’s Gulf Coast were fleeing in droves on Tuesday ahead of Hurricane Milton’s predicted landfall, in what officials said was likely to be the biggest evacuation the state has seen since Hurricane Irma struck in 2017. Evacuees have faced hourslong traffic jams on highways and gas stations running out of fuel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: We Should Want Israel to Win
description: Even supporters of Palestinian statehood should want Hamas and Hezbollah to lose.
content: The world had better hope that Israel wins its wars against Hamas, Hezbollah, the Houthis and their masters in Tehran. By “wins,” I mean that Israel inflicts such costs on its enemies’ capacity to wage war that they accept that their interests, irrespective of their desires, are no longer served by fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: The Quick-Witted, Self-Lacerating James Blunt Would Like a Word
description: Twenty years after his hit “You’re Beautiful” turned him into an overnight star, the British singer and songwriter takes his music — and his haters — to task.
content: Twenty years ago this month, James Blunt was an unknown singer releasing his first album. The song that rapidly elevated him out of obscurity was “You’re Beautiful,” a lovelorn rhapsody about falling for a stranger on the subway while high on drugs, which hit No. 1 in 15 countries, including the United States. The smash helped turn his 2004 LP “Back to Bedlam” into a triple-platinum success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Waiting Hours for 3 Minutes in the Criterion Closet (Well, Van)
description: A mobile version of movie fans’ favorite stockroom drew hundreds of New York Film Festival visitors eager to experience what celebrities do in popular videos.
content: The hottest event at this year’s New York Film Festival isn’t a film at all. It’s a van.

author: By Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Harris Proposes Medicare Benefits for Home Care, Vision and Hearing
description: The vice president’s health care plan is meant to help Americans who are struggling to find affordable home care for themselves or aging relatives.

author: By Kate Morgan
title: Her Face Was Unrecognizable After an Explosion. A Placenta Restored It.

content: Fantasy birdhouses, monkey islands, U.F.O. abductions, poltergeist possessions, hillbillies, rockers, goths, stuffed animals, graffitied history books and colorful banners with humorous phrases (most of which can’t be printed in this newspaper): The work of the Detroit-born multimedia artist Mike Kelley has something for everyone.

title: Corrections: Oct. 8, 2024

source.name: The New York Times

title: Residents Flee Milton From Beach Towns Still Cleaning Up From Helene
description: A one-two punch along Florida’s Gulf Coast is confronting some residents with hard decisions, like whether to pack up for good.
content: On the barrier islands outside St. Petersburg, Fla., which were utterly crushed by Hurricane Helene’s storm surge two weeks ago, it was hard to tell where storm recovery ends and storm preparation for the approaching Hurricane Milton begins.

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: 13 Things We Learned From Harris’s Interview With Howard Stern
description: In a lengthy sit-down, the veteran radio host extracted an array of new details about Kamala Harris’s life.
content: For over an hour, Vice President Kamala Harris and the radio host Howard Stern bantered on Tuesday about the state of the country, former President Donald J. Trump, Ms. Harris’s cereal and workout preferences, and her favorite musicians and racecar drivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natan Odenheimer and Adam Rasgon
title: What We Know About the Israeli Forces Fighting in Lebanon
description: The Israeli military has sent troops from four divisions across the border into Lebanon, but has not publicly disclosed how many.
content: The Israeli military announced on Tuesday that a new division of soldiers, the 146th, was operating in southern Lebanon, signaling that it could be ramping up the ground invasion of its neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Biden Requires Lead Drinking-Water Pipes to be Replaced Nationwide
description: The “historic” rule aims to eliminate a major source of lead poisoning and comes a decade after a drinking-water crisis in Flint, Mich.
content: Marking the 10th anniversary of the water crisis in Flint, Mich., President Biden on Tuesday gave water utilities 10 more years to replace virtually every lead pipe in the country, imposing the strictest limits to date on a neurotoxin that is particularly dangerous to infants and children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Paulina Villegas and Meridith Kohut
title: A Cartel Double-Cross Turns a Mexican State Into a War Zone
description: An explosive deception has ripped apart one of Mexico’s most powerful criminal groups, the Sinaloa cartel, and ignited a war between the rival factions.
content: Bodies dumped on the side of the road. Gun battles in upscale neighborhoods. Tractor-trailers set aflame on the highway. People plucked from their cars by armed men in broad daylight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Natan Odenheimer, Ronen Bergman and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Sends More Soldiers Into Lebanon as Strikes Hit Beirut and Damascus
description: In an attack of its own, Hezbollah fired 180 “projectiles” into Israel, according to the Israeli military, which said most were intercepted.
content: Israel announced a new division had joined its invasion of southern Lebanon on Tuesday, signaling that it could be ramping up operations as it pounded the Beirut strongholds of Hezbollah. Two Israeli officials confirmed that Israel had also struck near the Iranian Embassy in Syria’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: 5 Irresistible Fall Train Trips
description: Why navigate crowded roads to get your fill of autumn colors when you can ride the rails and enjoy gorgeous scenery you can’t see from the highway?
content: The air is crisp, and the leaves are bursting into vivid hues. Maybe you’re planning a road trip to admire the beauty. But getting your fill of fall foliage from behind the wheel can turn into an awkward juggle between admiring the vistas and navigating traffic. If you hop on a train, you can give the scenery your full attention and view some sights you just can’t see from the highway. Here are five great American train rides that offer day trips for peak-autumn panoramas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: The Role of New York’s Lauded Looted Art Unit Is Challenged in Court
description: The fight is over an Egon Schiele drawing held by the Art Institute of Chicago that the Manhattan district attorney’s office seized as Nazi loot. But it has wider implications.
content: In what has been a celebrated effort to right old wrongs, the Manhattan district attorney’s art trafficking unit has returned more than 4,600 artifacts and artworks to countries and heirs after finding they had been looted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: Why a Measure to Protect Abortion Rights in New York May Be in Trouble
description: The statewide ballot measure, known as the Equal Rights Amendment, has become a target for Republican opponents who have cast it as an attack on family values.
content: New York, with its liberal bent and habit of electing Democrats, seems the sort of place where a statewide ballot measure to protect reproductive rights would be a shoo-in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: This Year’s October Surprise May Be That There Isn’t One
description: The polls are very, very stable in spite of events.
content: The first time a movie ever really surprised me was the 1997 film “Contact.” In it, humans are sent plans for a machine that, once built and used, appears to transport Dr. Ellie Arroway — played marvelously by Jodie Foster — through a wormhole to an alien planet. She experiences what feels like nearly a day on this other planet, but on Earth it appears she never went anywhere at all. She is grilled by members of Congress over claims that her journey was an elaborate hoax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael David Lukas
title: Grappling With the Talmud in the Midst of Crisis
description: What the words of ancient rabbis could and couldn’t teach me.
content: In late 2019, I came upon an article about Daf Yomi — the practice of reading a page of the Talmud every day over the course of seven and a half years — and decided to sign up for a daily email promising to shepherd me through the text, that famously dense compilation of arguments among ancient rabbis. My wife was diagnosed with cancer a year earlier, and after grappling with big questions about mortality and fate, I was looking for a bit of spiritual direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: With Kennedy on the Ballot, Vance Talks Public Health in Michigan
description: Senator JD Vance of Ohio spoke of the occurrence of “weird childhood diseases” that may be caused by “weird stuff” in the food and water supply.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio echoed some of the language of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. on public health and the environment during a campaign rally on Tuesday in Michigan, a state where Mr. Kennedy — an ally of former President Donald J. Trump — was still on the ballot as a third-party presidential candidate and potential spoiler in the crucial battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Lewis
title: A Taste for Vibes, and Sometimes Wine
description: Some Gen Z-ers and young millennials say the culture and aesthetics of wine meld with their lifestyles, whether they’re drinking or not.
content: When Erika Veurink was planning her wedding, she knew she wanted the reception to be at Sauced, a wine bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, known for blasting hip-hop and its disco-ball-adorned dance room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: That Gun Harris Told Oprah Winfrey About? It’s a Glock.
description: “And I’ve had it for quite some time,” Vice President Kamala Harris said on “60 Minutes.”
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has a Glock. And she has taken it to the shooting range.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Jenny Gross
title: China to Penalize European Brandy Imports, Striking Back at Car Tariffs
description: Beijing’s action came days after European nations moved toward tariffs on electric vehicles from China, and it included a threat to also hit pork and car imports.
content: Raising the stakes in a trade dispute with the European Union, the Chinese government said on Tuesday it would impose temporary penalties on brandy from Europe and was mulling broader tariffs on European goods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Jobs and Housing Help Fuel Rapid Growth in Tampa
description: The region has been transformed by a number of economic and environmental factors, including its reputation for relatively few major storms.
content: For 10,000 years, people have relied on the natural resources of Tampa Bay, with its seagrass meadows, mangrove forests and diverse array of fauna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Rebecca Robbins
title: On Drug Prices, Harris Pushes for Deeper Cuts While Trump Offers Few Specifics
description: Both have campaigned for lower prescription costs. Kamala Harris has promised to expand President Biden’s policies. Donald Trump is a wild card.
content: Insulin for $35 a month. A limit of $2,000 a year in out-of-pocket drug costs for older Americans. Billions of dollars in savings for Medicare resulting from drug negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamilton Cain
title: An Exquisite Queer Odyssey by a Literary Master
description: In Alan Hollinghurst’s new novel, “Our Evenings,” a Burmese English actor grapples with race and ambition, sexuality and love in a bigoted world.
content: Near the conclusion of Alan Hollinghurst’s languorous, elegant novel “Our Evenings,” the seventh from the Booker laureate, the elderly biracial narrator, Dave Win, a London actor famous for East Asian roles, bumps into Giles Hadlow, a Tory politician and dyed-in-the-wool nativist, at a literary festival held in a manor house. Both have just published books, but only one draws crowds. As a teenager Dave had benefited from the Hadlow Exhibition: a scholarship funded by Giles’s parents to attend Bampton, an eminent Berkshire public school (what we Yanks would call a prep school). Though Giles’s parents are Dave’s benefactors, Giles is not. Dave once spent a holiday at the Hadlow farm, where Giles, brawny and cruel, tormented him with slurs and half nelsons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnatan Reiss
title: Netanyahu Suggests Israel Killed Likely Replacements for Hezbollah’s Leader
description: Hashem Safieddine had been expected to succeed Hassan Nasrallah, his cousin. It was not immediately clear who “the replacement of the replacement” was.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu suggested in a video message released on Tuesday that Israel had not only killed the presumed successor of Hezbollah’s assassinated leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in airstrikes last week outside Beirut, but also the successor’s potential replacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Swerdlick
title: Harris Should Offer to Debate Trump Again — on Fox
description: There’s only one venue where Harris would have another opportunity to speak to 67 million people at once.
content: In the latest New York Times/Siena College poll, Kamala Harris leads Donald Trump by three points. She’s made strategic appearances on the podcasts “Call Her Daddy” and “All the Smoke.” Her new direct-to-camera ad is strong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: 3% of American High Schoolers Identify as Transgender, First National Survey Finds
description: A survey by the C.D.C. found high rates of sadness, bullying and suicide attempts among transgender and gender-questioning teenagers.
content: About 3.3 percent of high school students identify as transgender and another 2.2 percent are questioning their gender identity, according to the first nationally representative survey on these groups, published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and William K. Rashbaum
title: Top Deputy Mayor to Eric Adams Resigns, Intensifying Wave of Departures
description: Sheena Wright, the first deputy mayor of New York City, became the seventh senior leader to leave City Hall in the past few weeks, as federal investigations into the Adams administration widen.
content: Sheena Wright, a longtime ally of Mayor Eric Adams, has resigned from her post as first deputy mayor, making her the seventh senior official to leave the administration during a time of crisis in New York City government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terry Parris Jr. and Anna Diamond
title: The 10 Most Common Questions Teenagers Asked About the Election
description: Headway has received more than 500 questions from teens about this year’s presidential election. Here are their most frequently asked questions — and our answers.
content: Throughout 2024, Headway and Chalkbeat, a nonprofit news organization focused on education in America, have been in conversation with teenagers about the upcoming presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta and Lola Fadulu
title: In New York on Oct. 7, Honoring the Dead and Calling for an End to War
description: In the city, which is home both to the largest Jewish population outside Israel and to thousands of Palestinians, some gathered in protest and others in solemn remembrance.
content: Thousands of people gathered across Manhattan on Monday to commemorate the first anniversary of Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel, with groups on both sides of the conflict expressing their collective grief and outrage over the past year of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
title: CBS Rebukes Anchor Over Tense Interview With Ta-Nehisi Coates
description: Executives said the interview, conducted by the morning show anchor Tony Dokoupil, had fallen short of network editorial standards.
content: CBS News on Monday rebuked one of its star morning anchors, Tony Dokoupil, over an interview that he conducted last week with the author Ta-Nehisi Coates, in which Mr. Dokoupil challenged Mr. Coates’s views about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Ali Wong Dishes on Life After Divorce. Her Real Subject Is Fame.
description: Her gossipy portrait of singlehood as a celebrity is a sunny contrast to the darker view of her Netflix stablemate Hannah Gadsby.
content: The last time we saw Ali Wong doing standup, she was delivering an earnest tribute to her husband and their relationship. The final line of “Don Wong,” her 2022 special, went: “And that, single people, is what a healthy marriage looks like.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Poll Finds Support for Florida’s Abortion Ballot Measure Is Falling Short
description: Earlier surveys have shown higher support, but the state’s Republican governor is working hard to defeat the initiative.
content: A ballot measure that would establish a right to abortion in the Florida Constitution is not on track to pass in November, according to a poll by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Cade Metz and Katrina Miller
title: Nobel Physics Prize Awarded for Pioneering A.I. Research by 2 Scientists
description: With work on machine learning that uses artificial neural networks, John J. Hopfield and Geoffrey E. Hinton “showed a completely new way for us to use computers,” the committee said.
content: John J. Hopfield and Geoffrey E. Hinton received the Nobel Prize in Physics on Tuesday for discoveries that helped computers learn more in the way the human brain does, providing the building blocks for developments in artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeğinsu, Derek M. Norman and Christine Chung
title: On Florida’s West Coast, Airports, Amusement Parks and Hotels Close
description: Visit Florida, the state’s official tourism organization, warned that Hurricane Milton is expected to grow and remain “extremely dangerous.” The travel industry is taking extreme precautions.
content: Follow the latest updates as Hurricane Milton plows toward Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Wednesday Briefing: An Israeli Airstrike in Syria
description: Plus, revisiting Oppenheimer’s Communist ties.
content: Israel launched airstrikes yesterday on a residential building in the Syrian capital, Damascus, according to two Israeli officials who spoke anonymously. The attack, which landed near the Iranian Embassy, was an attempt by the Israeli military to assassinate a ranking Hezbollah official involved in weapons smuggling, they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Ephrat Livni
title: Biden Excoriated Netanyahu on Israel’s Conduct in the War, Woodward Book Says
description: The book, “War,” lays bare just how frustrated the president has become with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since the war in Gaza began.
content: President Biden has had a long and complicated relationship with Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu — one that has taken an especially intense turn in the year since the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attacks, as documented in a new book by the journalist Bob Woodward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: How Biden’s Middle East Policy Fell Apart
description: The journalist Franklin Foer traced the Biden administration’s diplomacy in the Middle East since Oct. 7 and emerged with an “anatomy of a failure.”
content: This episode is being published almost a year to the day after Hamas attacked Israel. I have tried writing different versions of this introduction, tried to write something up to that moment — and failed. Nothing I write is up to memorializing the horror of that day or of what has followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: What We’ve Heard From Teens About the 2024 Election
description: Since September, the Headway team has been asking teenagers across the country for their thoughts on the election. Here’s what we’ve heard so far.
content: Early in 2024, the Headway team, along with Chalkbeat, a nonprofit news organization focused on education in America, started talking with high school students about the upcoming presidential election. We wanted to understand how youth were processing an election in which age had become an issue, especially four years after young people turned out at among the highest levels since 18-year-olds received the right to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: How to See the ‘Once-in-a-Lifetime’ Comet Flaring in Our Night Skies
description: Comet Tsuchinshan-ATLAS is nearing Earth and getting brighter.
content: Look up, stargazers: A comet discovered last year is getting brighter as it makes its closest pass by Earth later this week, and this could be humanity’s last chance to see the comet before it disappears into the cosmic depths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Steven Lee Myers
title: Russia, China and Iran Intend to Stoke False Election Claims, Officials Warn
description: Intelligence officials said that foreign adversaries were planning to take advantage of another close U.S. election to undermine trust in the country’s democratic process.
content: Foreign efforts to undermine American democracy will continue after Election Day, U.S. intelligence officials said on Monday, with covert influence campaigns focused on questioning the validity of election results after polls close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Michael Rothfeld, Dana Rubinstein and Bianca Pallaro
title: City Hall Official Charged With Witness Tampering in Adams Inquiry
description: Mohamed Bahi, who resigned Monday from the mayor’s office of community affairs, was accused of instructing witnesses to lie to federal authorities.
content: Mayor Eric Adams’s former chief liaison to the Muslim community was arrested Tuesday on federal witness tampering and destruction of evidence charges that had grown out of the investigation that led to the mayor’s indictment last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan Says It Manipulated a Photo of (Slightly) Unkempt Cabinet Ministers
description: The episode provided political fodder for Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s critics and highlighted the country’s generally high standard of dress.
content: The slightly disheveled appearance of the Japanese cabinet ministers who posed for an official photo last week — wrinkled trousers here, a triangle of exposed dress shirt there — was the sort of thing that some observers might overlook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Kirtzman
title: Is New York Ready to Forgive Andrew Cuomo?
description: History has presented Mr. Cuomo with an opportunity. But it’s one that New York voters may not swallow.
content: Throughout his long political career, Eric Adams seemed to float effortlessly above a constant drumbeat of reports questioning his ethical conduct. Just before he won the New York City Democratic mayoral primary in 2021, an aide predicted the city would come to appreciate him as a “lovable rogue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: New York Has 7 Million Trees. Here Are 120 Great Ones.
description: The Parks Department is releasing a list of “great trees” for the first time since 1985. The commissioner loves a willow in Brooklyn.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a new list of “great trees” in New York City. We’ll also get details on the departures of a top official and two lower-level aides at City Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Acru, From the Atomix Team, Serves a Tasting Menu With an Australian Twang
description: Grand Army sets up shop in Threes Brewing, Ánimo! brings all-day Mexican breakfast to Midtown and more restaurant news.
content: Word of this restaurant by Daniel Garwood began seeping out in early summer, but opening dates were postponed with clockwork regularity. Landmark status and permits were a factor, the chef said. Now it’s set for early next week. Mr. Garwood is from Tasmania and has worked in Asia, Scandinavia and Belgium before landing the job of sous chef at Atomix in 2022. His partner here is NA:EUN Hospitality Group, known for Atomix, Atoboy, Naro and Seoul Salon, and it’s its first non-Korean venture. Mr. Garwood’s seasonal five- to six-course tasting menu ($95) includes stops at lamb, tomatoes, carrots and dessert, some with Australian references. He plans to lose the tomatoes in place of squash soon. À la carte dishes are served at the bar. (Oct. 16)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Does My Home Have Lead Pipes? And What Can I Do About Them?
description: New rules will require utilities to replace lead pipes nationwide. That will take time, but you can protect yourself by taking these steps.
content: Lead is a potent neurotoxin that can cause irreversible damage to the nervous system and the brain. It poses a particular risk to infants and children, impairing their cognitive development and causing behavioral disorders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker
title: Poll Finds Harris Rising as She Challenges Trump on Change
description: A national Times/Siena poll found Kamala Harris with a slim lead over Donald J. Trump. Voters were more likely to see her, not Mr. Trump, as a break from the status quo.
content: Follow along with the latest updates on Trump, Harris and the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Jeremiah Sullivan
title: What Does Utopia Look Like for Black Americans?
description: Aaron Robertson’s grandparents had a farm in Promise Land, Tenn. In a new book, he explores the history and meaning of such utopian communities for African Americans.
content: Looked at from a certain surface-level perspective, the whole notion of Black utopianism can seem to entail a paradox. As the literary scholar Charles Scruggs put it more than 30 years ago in “Sweet Home: Invisible Cities in the Afro-American Novel,” “Given what we know about the position of Black Americans within a racist society, the idea of a Black utopian city may seem absurd on the face of it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Isabelle Taft
title: Fears of Hurricane Milton Drive Millions From Their Homes in Florida
description: More than 5.5 million people were urged to leave Florida’s western coast, one of the largest evacuations in state history. Some who have stayed for previous storms decided to go this time.
content: The threat of Hurricane Milton to Florida’s densely populated Tampa Bay region led to one of the largest evacuations in the state’s history this week. Officials urged millions of people out of possible harm’s way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: What Is Hamas Capable of After a Year of War?
description: The Palestinian militant group fired rockets at Israel on the anniversary of its Oct. 7 attacks.
content: A year ago, Hamas’s deadly attacks on southern Israel prompted an Israeli military offensive against the group in Gaza. Tens of thousands of Palestinians have been killed in the Israeli attacks, including children; Israel says it has killed many Hamas fighters and commanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Sees Antisemitism in Only One Direction: On the Left
description: At an event marking the anniversary of Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel, Donald Trump claimed that antisemitism existed within the Democratic Party but not the Republican Party.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Monday blamed Democrats for antisemitism at an event commemorating the Oct. 7 Hamas terrorist attack on Israel, then claimed there was no antisemitism in the ranks of the Republican Party, even as his own endorsed candidate for governor in North Carolina is at the center of a scandal involving antisemitic remarks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Lange
title: Peter Hujar’s Only Book Is Back in Print. His Friends Say It’s About Time.
description: John Waters, Fran Lebowitz and other friends of the photographer, who died in 1987, remember an artist impatient for the recognition he’s only recently begun to receive.
content: The subjects of Peter Hujar’s arresting black-and-white photographs from the 1950s through the 1980s were the citizens of his New York: the famous and niche-famous, beloved friends and sometime boyfriends, smoldering artists and playful drag performers, leather-clad lovers and distinguished pets. Mr. Hujar published only one monograph in his lifetime, “Portraits in Life and Death,” which features figures like John Waters, Fran Lebowitz and Susan Sontag alongside dozens of nameless remains from the Palermo catacombs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi
title: A U.N. Official’s Payments: Zero Interest Loans, a Mercedes and a Tennis Sponsorship
description: The official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a businessman to whom he steered the organization’s funds, a court ruled. The U.N. got a song about the ocean.
content: A high-ranking United Nations official secretly took $3 million in gifts from a British businessman while he steered more than $58 million of the organization’s money to the man’s companies, according to a ruling from an internal U.N. court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Give Some Lip
description: Justin Werfel edges toward the endgame.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Budget Deficit Rises to $1.8 Trillion in 2024
description: New estimates from the Congressional Budget Office show continuing fiscal strain, despite steady economic growth.
content: America’s federal budget deficit rose to $1.8 trillion in the 2024 fiscal year, reaching the highest level in three years, according to new Congressional Budget Office estimates released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek, Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Will Trump Get Jail Time? We Looked at Similar Cases to Find Out.
description: Donald J. Trump faces sentencing on Nov. 26. The election three weeks earlier may determine not only if he returns to the presidency, but if he ends up behind bars.
content: In November, after voters decide whether to return Donald J. Trump to the White House, the judge who oversaw his criminal trial could send him to jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Removing Books From Libraries Often Takes Debate. But There’s a Quieter Way.
description: Weeding, or culling old, damaged or outdated books, is standard practice in libraries. But in some cases it is being used to remove books because of the viewpoint they express.
content: Thousands of books have been removed from schools and libraries over the past several years, often accompanied by stormy public meetings and acrimonious debate. But there is a quieter way books have been pulled from libraries — a process called weeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mosab Abu Toha and Derek Arthur
title: I Was a Teacher in Gaza. This Is What Haunts Me Now.
description: Since Oct. 7, 80 percent of the schools in Gaza have been damaged or destroyed. Mosab Abu Toha reflects on what has been lost.
content: The last time Mosab Abu Toha, a poet and teacher, was in a classroom in Gaza, it was to shelter with his students and their families, all seeking refuge from Israeli airstrikes. Since then, he and his family have fled Gaza, and they temporarily reside in the United States. In this audio essay, he shares what it means when classrooms cease being places of learning and become a family’s only hope for survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: debacle
description: This word has appeared in 259 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word debacle has appeared in 259 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 29 in “Separated From Co-Workers, Man Endures Freezing Night in the Rockies Before Rescue” by Hank Sanders:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France’s Government Survives a No-Confidence Vote
description: The outcome was not a surprise but signals a treacherous road ahead for the country’s divided legislature.
content: A no-confidence vote against the government of Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France was handily defeated on Tuesday. But there is more drama to come, as the lack of a legislative majority causes deep political uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vidhya Nagarajan and Annie Aguiar
title: The Real Housewives Weren’t There, but Their Fans Were
description: At a Bravo-themed brunch, we met some devoted watchers of “Vanderpump Rules,” “Below Deck” and other staples of reality television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: FEMA Chief: Hurricane Misinformation Is ‘Worst That I Have Ever Seen’
description: Deanne Criswell, who heads the agency, said the circulating falsehoods were hampering its work.
content: Disaster relief officials have issued several warnings this week that falsehoods and rumors spreading online about the government’s response to Hurricanes Helene and Milton have harmed relief efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Millions Are Fleeing Florida’s Gulf Coast Ahead of Milton
description: Also, the Supreme Court appeared open to limits on “ghost guns.” Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The threat of Hurricane Milton, a Category 5 storm now barreling toward Florida’s Gulf Coast, has prompted one of the largest evacuations in the state’s history. More than five million people have been ordered to find safer ground before Milton makes landfall tomorrow, causing a mass exodus that has clogged the highways and drained the area’s gas stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump and Republicans Bet Big on Anti-Trans Ads Across the Country
description: Republicans have spent tens of millions of dollars on the ads, part of an attempt to help them win over suburban female voters.
content: With just four weeks until the election, Donald J. Trump and Republican candidates nationwide are putting transgender issues at the center of their campaigns, tapping into fears about transgender women and girls in sports and about taxpayer-funded gender transitions in prisons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Is It Too Late Now to Say Sorry? 8 Songs for the High Holy Days.
description: Apology, forgiveness, moving on: These are some of humanity’s richest themes, and they have rich songs to match.
content: As Lindsay mentioned on Friday, she’s out on book leave for the rest of the month. Starting next week, a series of knowledgeable Times staffers will sub in to provide thoughtfully curated playlists each Tuesday. This week, however, you are stuck with me: a reporter on the Culture desk who has written about Dylan and the Dead, and whose current Spotify rotation includes CoComelon’s “Wheels on the Bus” and the “Encanto” soundtrack (possibly Lin-Manuel Miranda’s finest work).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Dan Kaufman, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rikki Novetsky, Stella Tan, Clare Toeniskoetter, Olivia Natt, Lisa Chow, Larissa Anderson, Elisheba Ittoop, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker, Alyssa Moxley and Chris Wood
title: How NAFTA Broke American Politics
description: Since its passage in 1993, the trade agreement has played an outsize role in presidential elections.
content: On the campaign trail, Donald Trump and Kamala Harris are constantly talking about trade, tariffs and domestic manufacturing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: So, Are You Pregnant Yet? China’s In-Your-Face Push for More Babies.
description: The government is again trying to insert itself into women’s childbearing decisions, knocking on doors and making calls with questions some find downright invasive.
content: The first time a government worker encouraged Yumi Yang to have a baby, she thought little of it. She and her husband were registering their marriage at a local office in northeastern China, and the worker gave them free prenatal vitamins, which she chalked up to the government trying to be helpful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Iran Crisis Ignites New Debate About Trump’s Nuclear Deal Exit
description: President Donald J. Trump labeled it “the worst deal in history.” But critics of the withdrawal say it prompted Iran to accelerate its nuclear program.
content: With Israel preparing to respond to the ballistic missile attack by Iran last week, Biden administration officials are more worried than ever that the United States could be dragged into an all-out war between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Greg Landry, Scrambling All-Pro Quarterback, Is Dead at 77
description: Known for his legs as well as for his arm, he was the last Detroit Lions quarterback to make the Pro Bowl for more than 40 years.
content: Greg Landry, who in the late 1960s and ’70s became a forerunner of the modern dual-threat quarterback and, after a glittering All-Pro season for the Detroit Lions in 1971, made the Pro Bowl — the last Lions quarterback to earn that distinction for more than 40 years — died on Friday in Detroit.
